header.survey_title: Matching Firms and Scientists: Evidence from a Randomized Control Trial in Croatia
header.survey_description:
This research study aims to investigate the effectiveness of matching firms with scientists by rigorously evaluating this support for firms in Croatia under the SCINERGY '24 Pilot.
The pilot is designed to introduce scientists who have relevant expertise to firms and assist their discussions.

Matchmakers coordinate the meetings, helping to overcome challenges, and providing professional support through intensive handholding and knowledge transfer on key questions related to IP regulations, partnership agreements, and certification processes, amongst others. The matched pairs of scientists and business work jointly on concrete projects during the matchmaking phase.

By comparing randomly selected pilot firms and non-selected comparison firms, we seek to establish causal relationships between matchmaking support and its corresponding outcomes, while also distinguishing the effects for various types of firms.

The following questions regard your beliefs on the likely impact of BEING OFFERED the full pilot, regardless of whether or not a firm decides to participate in it. It is simply the mean difference of the outcomes for the firms that get offered the assistance, compared to similar firms that do not.

question1.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the number of business-science collaboration agreements signed after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? Be aware that percentage points are different from percentages. Suppose that only 10% of the firms forms collaborations. If later they increase to 20%, this is a 100% increase, but only a 10 p.p. increase. 
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question1.column_1: Percentage Points Change in New Business-Science Collaboration
question1.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the new business-science collaboration agreements to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question2.title_question: Question 2 - R&D Grant Application Submitted for Funding
question2.subtitle_question:
On average, how many more R&D grant applications do you think the beneficiary firms will submit after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? 
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question2.column_1: Number of R&D Grant Application Submitted
question2.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the number of R&D grant application to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question3.title_question: Question 3 - Number of Scientists Engaged in R&D per Firm
question3.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the number of Scientists Engaged in R&D per Firm after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group?
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question3.effect_size: What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the number of new scientists to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question4.title_question: Question 4 - Firm's Utilization of Research Infrastructures
question4.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the Firm's Utilization of Research Infrastructures after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? 
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question4.column_1: Percentage Points Change in Use of Research Infrastructures
question4.effect_size: What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the use of new infrastructures to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question5.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the annual revenue after two years since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? 
Revenue is usually defined as the total amount of money received by the firm from its business activities during the course of a year. This includes income from sales of goods and services, rental income, interest, royalties, fees, commissions, and any other business income. It does not include sales tax collected directly from customers and remitted to tax authorities.  
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question5.column_1: Percentage Points Change in Annual Revenue
question5.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the annual revenue to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question6.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the annual net profit after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? 
Net profit is the amount of income that remains after all operating expenses, taxes, interest, and preferred stock dividends have been deducted from a company's total revenue.  
 _Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question6.column_1: Percentage Points Change in Annual Net Profit
question6.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the annual net profit to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question7.subtitle_question:
On average, how much do you think the Scinergy'24 would CHANGE the number of full-time employees after six months since firms received the matchmaking support, compared to non-beneficiaris firms from the comparison group? 
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs and they should add to 100%._
question7.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the number of employees to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question8.title_question: Question 8 - Positive Impact on Employment in a Neighbouring Country
question8.subtitle_question:
Suppose we found the impact on employment in one of these other neighboring countries was 10%, with a 95% confidence interval of [+5%., +15%]. That is, the Scinergy'24 in this other country is estimated to have increased employment by 10% compared to a control group, and it is very likely the effect is between 5 and 15 percent. How, if at all, would this change your beliefs about the impact on employment in Croatia?
_Please look again at the answers you gave in Question 7. If you want to update your estimate insert the new distribution of probabilities, otherwise insert again the same distribution as you did above._
question8.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the number of employees to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question9.title_question: Question 9 - Negative Impact on Employment in a Neighbouring Country
question9.subtitle_question:
What if, instead, we had found that employment actually fell 5 percent in this other country relative to the control group, with a 95% confidence interval of [-10%., 0%]. That is, the Scinergy'24 in this other country is estimated to have led slightly firms to shrink their labor force compared to a control group, and it is very likely the effect is between -10 and 0 percent. How, if at all, would this change your beliefs about the impact on employment in Croatia?
_Please look again at the answers you gave in Question 7. If you want to update your estimate insert the new distribution of probabilities, otherwise insert again the same distribution as you did above._
question9.effect_size: - What would be the minimum effect size you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer in percentage points, e.g. if you would want the number of employees to increase by at least 5% against the comparison group, you should give 5 as your answer.

question10.subtitle_question:
In statistics, the correlation is a measure of how strongly two outcomes are linearly related. The correlation lies between -1 and 1. A correlation of -1 means that variables move perfectly in the opposite direction to one another, so that if one is high, the other is low. A 0 correlation means no relationship between them, while a correlation of +1 means the two move linearly together. A positive number between 0 and 1 means the two don't move perfectly together, but that you are somewhat more likely to see positive impacts in one variable when you see them somewhere else.
To make sure this is clear, let's first consider an example on the weather. What do you think is the correlation between the temperature on a Saturday and on a Sunday by looking at temperatures of all the weekends in a year?
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs._

question11.title_question: Question 11 - Correlation Between Treatment Estimates in Croatia and Those in Another Country
question11.subtitle_question:
We would like you to express your beliefs about the correlation you would expect to see between treatment estimates in Croatia and those in another country in the region. A negative correlation means you think if Scinergy'24 has a negative impact somewhere else this makes it more likely it has a positive impact in Croatia. A 0 correlation means no relationship between what you find elsewhere and what you expect to see in Croatia, while a positive correlation means if you think that when programs find a high impact somewhere else you will be more likely to also find a high impact in Croatia.
_Please allocate the probabilities in the cells corresponding to your beliefs._
question11.effect_size: - What would be the minimum correlation you would want to see in order to consider scaling up Scinergy'24 to more firms? Express your answer with a value between -1 and 1.
